description: Black hole thermodynamics (Hawking radiation, Bekenstein-Hawking entropy) and distance computations in Schwarzschild spacetime. Combines quantum effects with classical geometry, plus spacetime interval and geodesic distance calculations.

operations.name: compute_hawking_radiation
operations.description: Compute Hawking temperature and evaporation rate for Schwarzschild black hole. Quantum field theory in curved spacetime predicts black holes emit thermal radiation with temperature T_H = ℏc³/(8πGMk_B). Black holes evaporate over time, losing mass via Hawking radiation.
operations.mathematical_formula: Hawking temperature: T_H = ℏc³/(8πGMk_B) ≈ 6.17×10⁻⁸ K × (M_☉/M). Evaporation time: τ = 5120πG²M³/(ℏc⁴) ≈ 2.1×10⁶⁷ (M/M_☉)³ years. Luminosity: L = ℏc⁶/(15360πG²M²) (Stefan-Boltzmann for black body).
implementation_notes: Hawking temperature: T_H = ℏ/(8πMk_B) in geometric units (c=G=1)
Surface gravity: κ = 1/(4M) → T_H = ℏκ/(2πk_B) (Unruh temperature)
Evaporation rate: dM/dt ∝ -1/M² (smaller BHs evaporate faster)
Evaporation time: τ ∝ M³ (stellar-mass BH: τ ~ 10⁶⁷ years >> age of universe)
Primordial BHs (M ~ 10¹⁵ g): evaporating now (τ ~ 13.8 Gyr)
Hawking radiation: thermal spectrum (black body at T_H)
Information paradox: unitarity vs. thermal radiation
Observable: primordial BH evaporation (gamma-ray bursts?)

test_cases.note: T_H ≈ 62 nK, τ ≈ 10⁶⁷ years (far exceeds age of universe)

test_cases.name: Supermassive black hole (M=10⁹ M_☉)
test_cases.note: T_H ≈ 0.06 pK, extremely cold, negligible evaporation

test_cases.name: Primordial black hole (M=10¹⁵ g, evaporating now)
test_cases.note: T_H ≈ 123 GeV, τ ≈ 13.8 Gyr (age of universe), explosive final evaporation

test_cases.name: Micro black hole (M=1 kg, LHC scale)
test_cases.note: T_H ≈ 10²³ K, evaporates in 10⁻²⁶ seconds (Planck time scale)

test_cases.name: Geometric units (M=1)
test_cases.note: T_H = 1/(8π) ≈ 0.0398 in geometric units

edge_cases.name: Planck mass black hole (M=M_P ≈ 2.18×10⁻⁸ kg)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: T_H ≈ T_Planck ≈ 1.42×10³² K. Quantum gravity regime: semiclassical approximation breaks down. Evaporation time: τ ≈ t_Planck ≈ 5.4×10⁻⁴⁴ s.

edge_cases.name: Zero mass (degenerate)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: Error: T_H → ∞, evaporation rate diverges. No black hole (naked singularity or Minkowski space).

edge_cases.name: Negative mass (unphysical)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: Error: negative mass unphysical. Schwarzschild solution requires M > 0.

operations.name: compute_bekenstein_hawking_entropy
operations.description: Compute Bekenstein-Hawking entropy of Schwarzschild black hole. Black hole entropy proportional to horizon area: S = k_B A/(4ℓ_P²) = k_B c³ A/(4Gℏ) where A = 16πM² is horizon area. Fundamental connection between gravity, thermodynamics, and quantum mechanics.
operations.mathematical_formula: Bekenstein-Hawking entropy: S = k_B c³ A/(4Gℏ) where A = 4πr_s² = 16πM² (horizon area). In geometric units: S = A/4 = 4πM². Holographic principle: S ∝ A (not volume). Information capacity: N_bits = A/(4ℓ_P² ln(2)).
implementation_notes: Entropy: S = A/4 in geometric units (ℏ=c=G=k_B=1)
Horizon area: A = 4π(2M)² = 16πM²
Planck length: ℓ_P = √(Gℏ/c³) ≈ 1.616×10⁻³⁵ m
Planck area: A_P = ℓ_P² ≈ 2.61×10⁻⁷⁰ m²
Entropy per Planck area: S/A = k_B/(4ℓ_P²) ≈ 1 bit per Planck area
Holographic principle: maximum entropy scales with area, not volume
Information paradox: S increases during collapse, but Hawking radiation thermal
Black hole thermodynamics: dM = (κ/8π)dA + Ω_H dJ (first law)

test_cases.name: Solar mass black hole
test_cases.note: S ≈ 10⁵⁴ k_B, N_bits ≈ 10⁵⁴ bits (enormous information capacity)

test_cases.name: Supermassive black hole (M=10⁹ M_☉)
test_cases.note: S ∝ M²: entropy scales quadratically with mass

test_cases.name: Primordial black hole (M=10¹⁵ g)
test_cases.note: Small BH: S ≈ 10²⁶ k_B, still enormous

test_cases.name: Planck mass black hole (M=M_P)
test_cases.note: S ≈ k_B (one bit of information), minimum entropy BH

test_cases.name: Geometric units (M=1)
test_cases.note: S = 4πM² = 4π ≈ 12.57 in geometric units

edge_cases.name: Planck mass black hole (quantum gravity regime)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: S ≈ k_B (one bit). Quantum gravity corrections important. Semiclassical formula breaks down. Horizon area ≈ Planck area.

edge_cases.name: Zero mass (degenerate)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: Error: S = 0, A = 0. No black hole, no entropy. Minkowski spacetime.

edge_cases.name: Comparison with ordinary matter
edge_cases.expected_behavior: BH entropy (S ≈ 10⁵⁴ k_B) >> ordinary matter entropy (S ≈ 10⁵⁷ k_B for Sun). Black holes are maximum entropy objects for given mass.

operations.name: compute_distance_schwarzschild
operations.description: Compute spacetime interval (invariant distance) between two events in Schwarzschild spacetime. Uses metric: ds² = -(1-2M/r)dt² + (1-2M/r)⁻¹dr² + r²dΩ². Returns timelike (ds²<0), spacelike (ds²>0), or null (ds²=0) classification.

event1.description: First event coordinates [t₁, r₁, θ₁, φ₁]

event2.description: Second event coordinates [t₂, r₂, θ₂, φ₂]

proper_distance.description: Proper distance √(ds²) if spacelike, or proper time √(-ds²) if timelike

coordinate_separation.description: Coordinate differences: Δt, Δr, Δθ, Δφ

is_causally_connected.description: True if timelike or null (causal connection possible)

operations.mathematical_formula: Schwarzschild metric: ds² = -(1-2M/r)dt² + (1-2M/r)⁻¹dr² + r²(dθ² + sin²θ dφ²). For infinitesimal separation: ds² = g_μν dx^μ dx^ν. Timelike: ds²<0 (massive particles), Spacelike: ds²>0 (no causal connection), Null: ds²=0 (light rays).
implementation_notes: Metric components: g_tt = -(1-2M/r), g_rr = (1-2M/r)⁻¹, g_θθ = r², g_φφ = r²sin²θ
Spacetime interval: ds² = g_μν Δx^μ Δx^ν (for small separations)
Timelike (ds²<0): proper time τ = √(-ds²), causal connection
Spacelike (ds²>0): proper distance σ = √(ds²), no causal connection
Null (ds²=0): light-like separation, photon path
Invariant: all observers agree on ds² (coordinate-independent)
For large separations: integrate along geodesic

test_cases.name: Spacelike separation (same time, different locations)
test_cases.note: ds² = (1-0.2)⁻¹×100 = 125, σ = √125 ≈ 11.18 (approximate for large Δr)

test_cases.name: Null separation (light ray)
test_cases.note: ds² = 0 for photon: -(1-0.2)×80 + 0 = 0 (approximately)

test_cases.name: Angular separation (same r, t, different θ)
Near horizon (r=2.1M)
test_cases.note: ds² = -(1-2/2.1)×100 ≈ -4.76, extreme time dilation

edge_cases.name: At event horizon (r=2M)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: ds² = 0 (null). Coordinate singularity: g_tt = 0 at horizon. Schwarzschild time becomes null coordinate. Use Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates.

edge_cases.name: Inside horizon (r<2M)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: ds² > 0 (spacelike). Inside horizon: t becomes spacelike, r becomes timelike. Schwarzschild coordinates pathological.

edge_cases.name: Large separation (geodesic integration needed)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: Linear approximation invalid for Δr >> r. Integrate ds along geodesic: s = ∫√(g_rr) dr. Use sch_032 for accurate geodesic distance.

operations.name: compute_geodesic_distance
operations.description: Compute geodesic distance (proper length or proper time) along a spacelike or timelike path in Schwarzschild spacetime. Integrates metric along path: s = ∫√|g_μν dx^μ dx^ν|. More accurate than linear approximation for extended paths.

path.description: Path as array of spacetime points [[t₁,r₁,θ₁,φ₁], [t₂,r₂,θ₂,φ₂], ...]

geodesic_distance.description: Total geodesic distance (proper time for timelike, proper length for spacelike)

is_geodesic.description: True if path is a geodesic (extremal length)

operations.mathematical_formula: Geodesic distance: s = ∫√|ds²| = ∫√|g_μν dx^μ dx^ν|. For timelike: τ = ∫√(-ds²) (proper time). For spacelike: σ = ∫√(ds²) (proper length). Integrate along path using numerical methods (trapezoidal, Simpson, adaptive quadrature).
implementation_notes: Integrate metric along path: s = ∫√|g_μν (dx^μ/dλ)(dx^ν/dλ)| dλ
Parameterize path by affine parameter λ ∈ [0,1]
For timelike: proper time τ = ∫√(-g_μν u^μ u^ν) dλ
For spacelike: proper length σ = ∫√(g_μν dx^μ dx^ν) dλ
Adaptive integration: higher accuracy for curved regions
Check geodesic condition: D²x^μ/Dλ² = 0 (parallel transport of tangent)
For geodesics: use geodesic equations (sch_011, sch_013)

test_cases.name: Radial path (r=10M to r=20M, t=const)
test_cases.note: σ = ∫√(g_rr) dr ≈ 11.18 (curved space longer than coordinate distance)

test_cases.name: Temporal path (t=0 to t=10, r=10M)
test_cases.note: τ = ∫√(-g_tt) dt = √(1-0.2)×10 ≈ 8.94 (time dilation)

test_cases.name: Circular path (r=10M, θ=π/2, φ=0 to 2π)
test_cases.note: Circumference: C = 2πr = 62.83 (flat at constant r)

test_cases.name: Geodesic (free fall from r=10M to r=5M)
test_cases.note: Free fall geodesic: proper time from sch_011

test_cases.name: Near horizon path (r=2.5M to r=2.1M)
test_cases.note: Near horizon: geodesic distance >> coordinate distance (extreme curvature)

edge_cases.name: Path crossing horizon
edge_cases.expected_behavior: Mixed path: timelike outside, coordinate singularity at r=2M. Use Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates for smooth crossing. Schwarzschild coordinates break down.

edge_cases.name: Null geodesic (photon path)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: Geodesic distance = 0 (ds²=0 for photons). Use affine parameter λ instead of proper time. Integrate: ∫dλ.

edge_cases.name: Non-geodesic path (accelerated)
edge_cases.expected_behavior: Static observer (hovering): non-geodesic (requires thrust). Proper time τ < geodesic proper time (free fall). is_geodesic=false.
